subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 5, Lambas and Fundamentals
msgSnippet: I would also like a chance to define categories to run through more simple means. Integrated IDE support would be nice of course, but something like parameter
messageBody:
I would also like a chance to define categories to run through more simple
means. Integrated IDE support would be nice of course, but something like
parameter to set would help for starters.

I do not use the suites or categories right now but I do have tests that
are too slow for me to run all the time. I also do not want to maintain
separate suite classes but rather prefer to just right-click on a package
in IntelliJ and select "run tests". And repeating that from the menu if I
so prefer.

I like to group my tests by what they test and not have many source trees,
so currently I just temporarily disable some tests if they bother me, run
tests for a chosen package, and the whole set later.


On 23 January 2013 11:58, Mark Levison <mark@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
> Kevin, Colin and anyone else who is interested,
>
> Let's imagine the scenario here. I show up at client site as part of a two
> week engagement. During the 3 days of training we discuss Hill's definition
> of a Microtest; SPiFFy; etc. Now they all understand no **good** unit test
> touches the file system, database, network etc. In addition they've groked
> the value of creating only a small object graph for each test, max 7-8
> objects.
>
> Here comes the hard part, they've got legacy code. They sincerely want to
> do good stuff going forward, but their tests take ~25 minutes to run.
> Profiling indicates that there are ~35 tests over ~20 test classes that are
> slow. In almost every case slow tests are mixed in with fast tests. In
> addition many of these slow tests could be made fast (and more valuable) if
> we just made some clever use of fakes. However this changeover will take
> easily a couple of months of part time effort.
>
> In the world of NUnit we would just mark these as members of the category
> slow. In JUnit we either:
>
> - mark them as members of the category slow and resort to @suite
> annotations
> - mark them as members of the category slow and use maven tricks - helps
> the build server but not the individual developer running eclipse
> - move the slow tests to a separate source tree. Works well when you
> intentional write slow tests from scratch but not so much when you inherit
> this existing mess.
>
> As it stands I can waste alot of time with a client trying to overcome this
> issue when we should be practicing TDD, Mikado method, etc.
>
> Again my key point for JUnit 5 before discussing new things like Lambda's I
> think the challenge should be to make the existing functionality as simple
> to use as possible.
>
>
> Cheers
